9:53 Do you believe in science?
I barely, exactly for this reason.
If I have to agree with another scientist, it could either mean he is correct or wrong.
How do I know if he is correct or wrong ? I cannot.
Because, If I'm getting his exact result - I'm either correct because he is correct, or wrong because he's wrong.
But if I'm not getting his result - either he is wrong, I am wrong or we're both wrong.
And the more "facts" there are - the more confusing it gets
Hence, I conclude that I cannot really believe the science.
My method of being in the safe zone is by using math's probability concept - the more people agree upon something, it is more likely true.
Of course, that is imperfect - because if the majority is wrong, then you're wrong as well - but it's better than nothing.

I just wanted to say thank you for using a clip of a female scientist a couple of minutes in! I watch a lot
of informational videos, and my little sister occasionally watches them too. We just had a conversation about what you mentioned about 6 minutes in about how the field has historically been dominated by particular demographics, and she seemed to have picked up the idea that only men are scientists, until that little clip a couple minutes in. After she commented on this, I put on Crash Course's video about Marie Curie and a few others, and watched her face light up as I introduced her to women who I'm hoping will be her role models in the future.
It's crazy to me that an 8 year old born in today's world could still have reason to internalize the message that they can't be something they want to be based on gender or any other arbitrary measure of ability. Until something quitely subverts that message.
Thanks Crash Course (and SciShow) for being the place I can rely on to accurately represent all the demographics of your viewership, and thanks for just doing the little things you can that prove to a little girl that being a part of the STEM fields isn't a pipe dream. One of the many reasons I love this channel!

Very nice video and clarity in ideas. But problem is when you stick with the term 'science' rather than tendency of knowledge gaining of not just material world but immaterial world too.  Of course, science was derived from the Latin word scientia (knowledge) in 16th century and the term scientist was coined in 19th century. And this is was the time when according to Thomas Kuhn science revolutionized. More over, many claim that before 16th or 17th century, there was no science but just natural philosophy. Another problem is when your history becomes eurocentric, what about the non-european equivalent terms of science? For me, science begun right from the emergence of humanity. Many scientific revolutions occurred between stone age tool making and Artificial intelligence. All these are the products of knowledge. When our ancestors invented civilization, there the basic scientific tools like observational, empirical, rational knowledge were used. For example, gastronomy; a kitchen was itself a scientific lab. By the age of 2nd millenium BCE, our ancestors started to write down the knowledge in Egypt and Mesopotamia, the Hindu Vedas means knowledge, by the era of 6th century BCE, our ancestors started to find the laws of nature. It happened in India first, then in Greece and then in China. Logic and philosophy originated in India in 8th century BCE in Upanishadic period. Greece was heavily influenced by Egypt and Babylon in sense of material culture and with India in immaterial culture. French anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss rightly said that Totemism is a sort of logic.

Glad to see you've taken on this project. I think the history of science is fundamental to anyone truly understanding science. I am curious for some response. The motto Nullius in Verba - "On no ones word" is truly fundamental to scientific inquiry, but it seems some non-scientists have taken this a bit too literally. The body of scientific knowledge is so vast it's impossible for anyone to investigate every "truth" beyond the word of experts, and this results in some lay people refuting such irrefutable events as the Apollo Moon landings by effectively claiming "we cannot take NASA at their word". You have a whole cast of people using scientific language to subvert and bastardize legitimate scientific explanations and achievements. Even the very unscientific hard creationist movement of men like Ken Ham uses scientific language with an air of mistrust for the word of legitimate scientists, and this extends to politicians who dispute evidence of climate change with a simple dismissal. My comment has devolved into a rant, but any thoughts on teaching students how to respect the conclusions of experts when they don't have the time or ability to test the explanations themselves?

A great intro for a very interesting subject. But it would be more accurate to call the course 'History and Philosophy of Science'.
When we're asking about 'Stuff' and how this concept has been treated throughout history, we're talking about 'History of Science'. We assume that there is something called 'Stuff' and we're just studying History.
But we're asking about what is stuff and how this idea has been perceived, then we're doing Philosophy. And everything is better with a bit of Philosophy.

An someone who focused on philosophy of science in university, I'm glad to see this important subject getting attention at Crash Course. The shout out to Kuhn and Foucault gives me a huge confidence boost that it's going to be of good service to the viewers. On the other hand, the idea that we need to "science" out of ecological collapse could be a huge red flag for the tone of the series. I hope it doesn't fall into techno-optimism too deeply and approaches science with a healthy skepticism despite having to be careful around those who abuse science like anti-vaxxers, those against GMOs, or flat Earthers / creationists. These positions generally can't really be reasoned with - so a better approach is always to shatter faith and religiosity within science than those who irrationally fear or reject it. Quite a monumental task, of course, but one I'm hoping to see Crash Course navigate well as they serve as an introduction and first impression for often propagandized and dogmatized history of science.
